results.content: Getting past the little outdated quirks, it's a pretty good guide
results.content_html: Getting past the little outdated quirks, it's a pretty good guide

results.content:
I've taken a few different Udemy courses now with various instructors. I've found that I like Piotr's teaching style the best out of all the instructors I've taken. He has the right balance of coding and in depth explanation, which is exactly what I was hoping to get when I purchased this course. 

Piotr provides some excellent insight into the inner workings of Symfony and does an awesome job of showing how you would begin to build a larger application utilizing the proper Symfony components. Symfony is a huge framework and I don't think I would've been able to dig into the documentation and take it apart as quickly on my own. 

I highly recommend this course to anyone who wants to get their hands dirty and jump right into the meat of how Symfony works.

response.content: Thanks Nicholas, I highly appreciate it!

results.content_html:
I've taken a few different Udemy courses now with various instructors. I've found that I like Piotr's teaching style the best out of all the instructors I've taken. He has the right balance of coding and in depth explanation, which is exactly what I was hoping to get when I purchased this course.

Piotr provides some excellent insight into the inner workings of Symfony and does an awesome job of showing how you would begin to build a larger application utilizing the proper Symfony components. Symfony is a huge framework and I don't think I would've been able to dig into the documentation and take it apart as quickly on my own.

I highly recommend this course to anyone who wants to get their hands dirty and jump right into the meat of how Symfony works.

results.content:
The course is terrible. The speaker speaks so slow that there are huge pauses between the words even at 2x speed. He also has a very annoying accent and repeatedly pronounces Symfony wrong. 
There are miss-leading chapter names, which do not reflect the content of the videos.
The principles of how Symfony works are not explained as a concept. The speaker just uses what he needs for the course and says "this is so". I'm almost at the last chapter and I still don't know where to find all the possible configuration variables names, for an example.
I would have asked for my money back but I bought the course and started it a few weeks later, so I wasn't eligible for a refund.
results.content_html:

There are miss-leading chapter names, which do not reflect the content of the videos.

results.content:
This guy is by far the best instructor I've ever come across. I took his other Symfony 4 course and advanced my understanding of the Framework more in a week than I have in the past year. 

This course has filled a ton of gaps. He understands the complex learning curve and it's relationship to the content he covers thoroughly... a rarity in teaching, never mind coding complex Frameworks.

Just stick with the course.. you'll have that "Aha!" moment.

I'm working on my own Symfony 4 Framework based project(s) as I take this course... between Piotr, Github, and Google... its getting done!

Two of the most effective courses I've ever taken. I can't wait for what he puts out next.

By the way... I'm using a WAMP dev server on Windows 10 .. I just prefer it over Vagrant and the Virtual Box. If you know your way around WAMP this will be a snap. 

Just install: "composer require apache-pack --dev"

...and the Symfony debug bar will work on your Apache server.

Ian

response.content: Thank you Ian, I appreciate it a lot! Sure, there's more coming!
response.content_html: Thank you Ian, I appreciate it a lot! Sure, there's more coming!

Just stick with the course.. you'll have that "Aha!" moment.

I'm working on my own Symfony 4 Framework based project(s) as I take this course... between Piotr, Github, and Google... its getting done!

Two of the most effective courses I've ever taken. I can't wait for what he puts out next.

By the way... I'm using a WAMP dev server on Windows 10 .. I just prefer it over Vagrant and the Virtual Box. If you know your way around WAMP this will be a snap.

Just install: "composer require apache-pack --dev"

...and the Symfony debug bar will work on your Apache server.

Ian

results.content:
The trainer seems really competent in his domain but lacks a lot of pedagogy (in this course). He does not always explain why we have to write a particular function. For example in Section 3, he doesn't tell what all these notions can be used for in the final application. 
The quality of the microphone can be improved, the sound is not clear and it is necessary to put the volume of the computer almost to the maximum to hear. He should also talk with more energy. 
As a beginner in Symfony, I was not able to complete the course.

results.content:
Assumptions made that users already know what a lot of things are

Quite often what is being displayed on the screen is out of sync with what the instructor is saying at the time eg. the instructor has already  performed a task a few seconds before they explain what they are doing, and its very hard to follow

Poor explanation of what the symfony core files are

The introduction to controllers within symfony is just "Create a blog controller", and is over in 5 seconds.

Hard to stay engaged due to the monotonous tone

response.content: Thanks for feedback. The course is almost 14 hours long, so you will have a chance to see how controllers look like in more detail. I can't explain everything at once, in a single lecture. I'm not trying to make any assumptions, but some things (like development environment setup) are out of scope of this course, so they are talked about briefly only to get you going. I'd be interested to hear where exactly did you feel I made assumptions, so maybe I can explain it better. Also, not everything might be in perfect sync, as I'm trying to explain concepts sometimes, not what I'm doing on the screen in the exact moment. Thanks again and sorry that you had worse experience than you expected, if you'd like to point out when you felt left out I'd be happy to hear from you (PM me if you will), I'd like to make this course better.
response.content_html: Thanks for feedback. The course is almost 14 hours long, so you will have a chance to see how controllers look like in more detail. I can't explain everything at once, in a single lecture. I'm not trying to make any assumptions, but some things (like development environment setup) are out of scope of this course, so they are talked about briefly only to get you going. I'd be interested to hear where exactly did you feel I made assumptions, so maybe I can explain it better. Also, not everything might be in perfect sync, as I'm trying to explain concepts sometimes, not what I'm doing on the screen in the exact moment. Thanks again and sorry that you had worse experience than you expected, if you'd like to point out when you felt left out I'd be happy to hear from you (PM me if you will), I'd like to make this course better.

results.content: good course
results.content_html: good course

results.content:
This is a Fantastic Course for Symfony exceeds expectations !!

Piotr is an experienced, knowledgeable and serious developer.
  
This course not only helped me to learn the inner workings of Symfony but also improve my OO php syntax, improve on git, get a better understanding of development stages, introduced me to cloud deployment ... even CI.CD. 
From where I stand as a beginner, is a mini MVC developer course.

Couldn't recommend it enough. 

You will certainly learn.

Thanks Piotr.

Also, if you are a beginner who hasn't has contact with Object Oriented Programming don't go for Symfony. Get acquainted with OOP first (don't miss type hinting, annotations, namespace).
results.content_html:
This is a Fantastic Course for Symfony exceeds expectations !!

Piotr is an experienced, knowledgeable and serious developer.

This course not only helped me to learn the inner workings of Symfony but also improve my OO php syntax, improve on git, get a better understanding of development stages, introduced me to cloud deployment ... even CI.CD.
From where I stand as a beginner, is a mini MVC developer course.

Couldn't recommend it enough.

You will certainly learn.

Thanks Piotr.

Also, if you are a beginner who hasn't has contact with Object Oriented Programming don't go for Symfony. Get acquainted with OOP first (don't miss type hinting, annotations, namespace).

results.content:
This is far the best Symfony course I ever attended. Piotr is a great instructor, he cover all the aspects to take you from a complete beginner to a junior Symfony 4 developper.

After completing this course, you will be able to use Symfony 4 Framework for your own project, and by reading the Symfony documentation and cookbook, you will even be able to learn anything you may need in your project that Piotr may not have covered as you now have all the basics.
results.content_html:
This is far the best Symfony course I ever attended. Piotr is a great instructor, he cover all the aspects to take you from a complete beginner to a junior Symfony 4 developper.

After completing this course, you will be able to use Symfony 4 Framework for your own project, and by reading the Symfony documentation and cookbook, you will even be able to learn anything you may need in your project that Piotr may not have covered as you now have all the basics.

results.content:
Amazing course! In-depth explanations, perfect talking pace, talks slow and is direct to the point.
I had no previously knowledge in Symfony before starting, and this course gave me the confidence to start developing real world apps using Symfony. You will learn a lot of the Symfony framework, and some other cool techniques like Ajax Calls, Testing, Server configuration and Continous Deployment of your code.
results.content_html:
Amazing course! In-depth explanations, perfect talking pace, talks slow and is direct to the point.
I had no previously knowledge in Symfony before starting, and this course gave me the confidence to start developing real world apps using Symfony. You will learn a lot of the Symfony framework, and some other cool techniques like Ajax Calls, Testing, Server configuration and Continous Deployment of your code.

results.content:
I'm really sorry to leave a low rate. Piotr is a good teacher with whom I learnt a lot in this course. I'd leave a five stars if it weren't for the last section.

I had no previous experience in CircleCi and the scripts on the last section don't work. I could complete the course by reading Q&A of other students and searching from other sources.

The course is complete and interesting overall. However, it is two year old and it needs an update as soon as possible.

results.content: The course contains all you need to build your own app and then some more.
results.content_html: The course contains all you need to build your own app and then some more.

results.content:
The subject of the course is OK, good learning pace. 
I found a lot of mistakes in source code, e.g:
- Lesson "LocaleSubscriber..." arguments to service App\Event\LocaleSubscriber are array (time 7:38) changed without any information in 9:20.
- Lesson "Moving application code to production server" error in command -> dl.yarnpkg.com instead dl.yarnpkg/com
- Its hard to install application on DigitalOcean, see question https://www.udemy.com/learn-symfony-4-hands-on-creating-a-real-world-application/learn/v4/questions/5933998. I think its by incompatibility of the yarn package version.
- The same for working with CircleCI:
  - problem with yarn install,
  - problem with pre-deploy.sh (delete folder if they not exists, better: if [ -d /var/www/micropost_old ]; then sudo rm -R /var/www/micropost_old; fi)
- In lesson "Deployment job and ..." you connect to digitalOcean machine by $DROPLET_USER:$DROPLET_IP command (not working), 
but in next lesson you are using correct command. 

Generaly, I'm disappointed with chapters "Deploying Symfony4 on production environment" and "Automating the deployment process with CircleCi". I have lost a lot of time looking for the causes of problems and their solutions.
results.content_html:
The subject of the course is OK, good learning pace.
I found a lot of mistakes in source code, e.g:
- Lesson "LocaleSubscriber..." arguments to service App\Event\LocaleSubscriber are array (time 7:38) changed without any information in 9:20.
- Lesson "Moving application code to production server" error in command -> dl.yarnpkg.com instead dl.yarnpkg/com
- Its hard to install application on DigitalOcean, see question https://www.udemy.com/learn-symfony-4-hands-on-creating-a-real-world-application/learn/v4/questions/5933998. I think its by incompatibility of the yarn package version.
- The same for working with CircleCI:
- problem with yarn install,
- problem with pre-deploy.sh (delete folder if they not exists, better: if [ -d /var/www/micropost_old ]; then sudo rm -R /var/www/micropost_old; fi)
- In lesson "Deployment job and ..." you connect to digitalOcean machine by $DROPLET_USER:$DROPLET_IP command (not working),
but in next lesson you are using correct command.

Generaly, I'm disappointed with chapters "Deploying Symfony4 on production environment" and "Automating the deployment process with CircleCi". I have lost a lot of time looking for the causes of problems and their solutions.

results.content:
Great introduction to Symfony, with explanations of all the important parts of it.

Unfortunately there are some bugs in the examples and some components are not up to date. But I see fixing the problems that might occur, as good practices to get a little bit deeper into the topic. :)
results.content_html:
Great introduction to Symfony, with explanations of all the important parts of it.

Unfortunately there are some bugs in the examples and some components are not up to date. But I see fixing the problems that might occur, as good practices to get a little bit deeper into the topic. :)

results.content:
This course is a great introduction to Symfony 4, but there are a few issues that have been addressed by other users as well.

- I was almost gonna give up because installing Homestead / Vagrant just didn't work at all on my machine. I ended up using Docker, which was way more convenient. Piotr is aware of these issues, but it's taking quite long to fix now.
- He makes numerous mistakes during lessons. They get fixed later in the same lesson or in the following one, but it would've been better just to stop recording and start over, as it causes confusion.
- His pronunciation is so-so, and enthusiasm was kind of hard to find - which is a shame, as he is very, very knowledgable without any doubt.  

But; the most important thing is learning about Symfony, and that I've surely done. I feel I can confidently start a Symfony project now. All in all this course is recommended, even though it would be better with a few small adjustments.

(I didn't follow the deployment sections so I cannot comment on that.)
results.content_html:
This course is a great introduction to Symfony 4, but there are a few issues that have been addressed by other users as well.

- I was almost gonna give up because installing Homestead / Vagrant just didn't work at all on my machine. I ended up using Docker, which was way more convenient. Piotr is aware of these issues, but it's taking quite long to fix now.
- He makes numerous mistakes during lessons. They get fixed later in the same lesson or in the following one, but it would've been better just to stop recording and start over, as it causes confusion.
- His pronunciation is so-so, and enthusiasm was kind of hard to find - which is a shame, as he is very, very knowledgable without any doubt.

But; the most important thing is learning about Symfony, and that I've surely done. I feel I can confidently start a Symfony project now. All in all this course is recommended, even though it would be better with a few small adjustments.

(I didn't follow the deployment sections so I cannot comment on that.)

results.content:
Sometimes the code changes magically, without explanation. Lets say something is first shown in a way (not working state), but after a few minutes when the same code section is revisited, one can see that the code has been fixed, but the fix isn't mentioned. Sometimes you can find the answers for something similar that isn't working under Q&A.
Also the teaching pace isn't constant, too fast in some places.

results.content_html: Thanks for sharing your programming skill which is more useful for me to understand symfony.

results.content:
Bought this course to help me with a new job which uses a fully built  Symfony 4 application.

This course was great for helping me cover off a lot of the basics of Symfony and getting up to speed quickly. Great Job. 

A couple of things I would like to see more of:
* Symfony Forms (our application uses these extensively, I would like to see more advanced uses of Forms)
* PHPStorm. I started this course using Sublime Text 3 with lots of PHP autocomplete plugins. I think to do any Symfony you need PHPStorm. Otherwise there's so much more overhead involved. You should probably make this a recommendation at the start?
* Some use of Pagination would be cool. 
* Maybe some examples of calling a REST API? Everything was very DB heavy, perhaps include some lectures on calling out to a Public Weather API or something like that... 
* Caching - I didn't see anything to do with how Symfony caches data or translations etc. 

Other than that I've loved coding along and just bought the REST API course... Thank you for putting these together!
results.content_html:
Bought this course to help me with a new job which uses a fully built Symfony 4 application.

This course was great for helping me cover off a lot of the basics of Symfony and getting up to speed quickly. Great Job.

A couple of things I would like to see more of:
* Symfony Forms (our application uses these extensively, I would like to see more advanced uses of Forms)
* PHPStorm. I started this course using Sublime Text 3 with lots of PHP autocomplete plugins. I think to do any Symfony you need PHPStorm. Otherwise there's so much more overhead involved. You should probably make this a recommendation at the start?
* Some use of Pagination would be cool.
* Maybe some examples of calling a REST API? Everything was very DB heavy, perhaps include some lectures on calling out to a Public Weather API or something like that...
* Caching - I didn't see anything to do with how Symfony caches data or translations etc.

Other than that I've loved coding along and just bought the REST API course... Thank you for putting these together!

results.content:
This is a comprehensive introduction to Symfony by someone who knows the framework well.

The course as current recorded is a bit hard for beginners, since it assumes you know PHP well, including what's called "modern PHP" -- especially the improvements to language that came in with PHP 5.3 and PHP 5.5.  It's also a bit front loaded with the theory of the framework. I expect both of these will be fixed in future updates to the course. But once you get passed the first section, there's a lot of very useful and clear explanations of how the Symfony 4 framework works, and how to get work done in it. I recommend this course.

response.content: Thanks for your feedback Rob. The starting section would be overhauled to be more beginner friendly for sure, I'm on that.
response.content_html: Thanks for your feedback Rob. The starting section would be overhauled to be more beginner friendly for sure, I'm on that.

results.content_html:
This is a comprehensive introduction to Symfony by someone who knows the framework well.

The course as current recorded is a bit hard for beginners, since it assumes you know PHP well, including what's called "modern PHP" -- especially the improvements to language that came in with PHP 5.3 and PHP 5.5. It's also a bit front loaded with the theory of the framework. I expect both of these will be fixed in future updates to the course. But once you get passed the first section, there's a lot of very useful and clear explanations of how the Symfony 4 framework works, and how to get work done in it. I recommend this course.

results.content:
I'm very satisfied with this course. I haven't finished it yet but I think I can give initial view on this course.

Sometimes author omit quite important issues. However he often fill it up in next parts of course. I recomend you follow Symfony documentation, though.

It's not difficult to recognise that English isn't native language of him. Mine too, so sorry for all mistakes ;) For someone it can be a problem (not for me).

As regards as sound and voice... Quality should be a bit better. The hard cuts of voice in video are heard. It is a pity that commentary wasn't done without cuts.

Similar situation is with the screen recording. It could look better, more engaging.

To sum up THANKS for a great course (with small shortcomings) :)

results.content:
Update 2020/06/13:  
In my previous opinion I told you about the mess that this course was. The many hours I wasted trying to follow this dude having you use vagrant on a virtual machine instead of using a Wamp and how I regretted it. That the work was half done as instructions were only given for mac users and teacher was not providing any meaningful help at all.  That I thought he didnt seem to be a good teacher but I would keep you updated.. 
Here I am, getting back in it after almost a year..
Update 2020/06/13:  About a year I am resuming the course, a I am picking course where I left. I installed  Symfony using instructor's instructions.  Being one year later I didn't realize there was a Symfony 5 that went out in the meanwhile and I would be tempted to say I downloaded latest version and it's indeed the case. By following his instructions I got Symfony 5.1 instead of 4. I realized a bit later where stuff started being a tad different. that I didnt have the same version.  So I guess I should blame myself for getting wrong version and the teacher doesnt have to update course for silly people like me using version 5. Well some other instructors upgrade their course to keep up to date for future students and it's good for both old buyers and potential new students who are not buying something too old. But thing is I got version 5 by following his instructions which are clearly not future proof because composer allows user to specify version. I am adding a star because I actually appreciated teacher getting in details on topic that tutorials usually just skim. But thing is it comes at the cost of teacher skimming on topic he considered not requiring not much explanation, like the twig code to add stylesheet  and js on page.  To be honest I didnt care much because I have used Symfony in the past and those are mundane things that I am glad I didnt have to waste time on again but I am thinking of people learning Symfony... While in other courses like with  Maximillian Schwartzmuller the instructor types code as it goes and explains what he is doing. Here the instructor is  either 1) have typed config lines beforehand and just comments it out for the video (At beginning I was wondering why I didnt have those lines it's rather an unsettling thing to do and the guy  doesn't bother giving an explanation). Then for the first bootstrap template guy just has you copy paste the twig template from his file and as said i's a good thing for old timers but not that good for newcomers because how to appropriate twig if not typing stuff along. Supposedly there is also a file for the css but it's missing and we have to type it this time. There was a lot of stuff I couldnt figure out why it wasnt working in the config file but it was ok because it comes from my version not being version 4. And here my bootstrap template style is not working  and I have no clue why. Teachers spent a whole video on how controller was calling services and I quite liked this thorough study of the inner logic of the framework,  although quite a boring theoritical thing to start off a tutorial with for a beginner! But for the use of Webpack, the description of what it does and how it works is pretty vague. And I know I can't count on the teacher being around for students to help so I will look it up online as it must be quite a documented topic and faster than downgrading Symfony to version 4.  To be honest I am pretty sure that going on Sensiolabs website and following their free tutorials would be a better use of my time. And although I still haven't finished the course, I think it's pretty safe to give similar advise to potential buyers who are willing to learn Symfony. You might find there is a shortage of good lessons on this topic on Udemy but there is a lot of material online to learn it, and chances are it will be a better experience for you that this rough ride that are the lessons provided by this teacher.
In a nutshell: The teacher doesn't reply and help students and he doesn't keep course updated. And his course is not the smoothest experience you will get learning Symfony.  Works ok if you use it to refresh your experience with Symfony (But then not providing you much if you want to refresh it with latest version) but new students I would think twice.

The many hours I wasted trying to follow this dude having you use vagrant on a virtual machine instead of using a Wamp and how I regretted it. That the work was half done as instructions were only given for mac users and teacher was not providing any meaningful help at all. That I thought he didnt seem to be a good teacher but I would keep you updated..
Here I am, getting back in it after almost a year..
Update 2020/06/13: About a year I am resuming the course, a I am picking course where I left. I installed Symfony using instructor's instructions. Being one year later I didn't realize there was a Symfony 5 that went out in the meanwhile and I would be tempted to say I downloaded latest version and it's indeed the case. By following his instructions I got Symfony 5.1 instead of 4. I realized a bit later where stuff started being a tad different. that I didnt have the same version. So I guess I should blame myself for getting wrong version and the teacher doesnt have to update course for silly people like me using version 5. Well some other instructors upgrade their course to keep up to date for future students and it's good for both old buyers and potential new students who are not buying something too old. But thing is I got version 5 by following his instructions which are clearly not future proof because composer allows user to specify version. I am adding a star because I actually appreciated teacher getting in details on topic that tutorials usually just skim. But thing is it comes at the cost of teacher skimming on topic he considered not requiring not much explanation, like the twig code to add stylesheet and js on page. To be honest I didnt care much because I have used Symfony in the past and those are mundane things that I am glad I didnt have to waste time on again but I am thinking of people learning Symfony... While in other courses like with Maximillian Schwartzmuller the instructor types code as it goes and explains what he is doing. Here the instructor is either 1) have typed config lines beforehand and just comments it out for the video (At beginning I was wondering why I didnt have those lines it's rather an unsettling thing to do and the guy doesn't bother giving an explanation). Then for the first bootstrap template guy just has you copy paste the twig template from his file and as said i's a good thing for old timers but not that good for newcomers because how to appropriate twig if not typing stuff along. Supposedly there is also a file for the css but it's missing and we have to type it this time. There was a lot of stuff I couldnt figure out why it wasnt working in the config file but it was ok because it comes from my version not being version 4. And here my bootstrap template style is not working and I have no clue why. Teachers spent a whole video on how controller was calling services and I quite liked this thorough study of the inner logic of the framework, although quite a boring theoritical thing to start off a tutorial with for a beginner! But for the use of Webpack, the description of what it does and how it works is pretty vague. And I know I can't count on the teacher being around for students to help so I will look it up online as it must be quite a documented topic and faster than downgrading Symfony to version 4. To be honest I am pretty sure that going on Sensiolabs website and following their free tutorials would be a better use of my time. And although I still haven't finished the course, I think it's pretty safe to give similar advise to potential buyers who are willing to learn Symfony. You might find there is a shortage of good lessons on this topic on Udemy but there is a lot of material online to learn it, and chances are it will be a better experience for you that this rough ride that are the lessons provided by this teacher.
In a nutshell: The teacher doesn't reply and help students and he doesn't keep course updated. And his course is not the smoothest experience you will get learning Symfony. Works ok if you use it to refresh your experience with Symfony (But then not providing you much if you want to refresh it with latest version) but new students I would think twice.

results.content:
Not at all educational ...

- Explain quickly and on the surface the concepts;
- Explanations that go in all directions (we start with the service, then jump on the "voters" without knowing what it is)
- Not at all made to learn Symfony! You must know Symfony (rather well) before taking this course to understand what the instructor is doing
- Ask us to install PHPStorm, but do not explain its use at all. He imports class, initializes fields extremely fast without telling the user which keyboard shortcut he has used.

results.content: I'm totally new to Symfony. I have some experience with  PHP, html, javascript. From the beginning of the lecture, this instructor doesn't tell the student exact reason why do I need to install Laravel, Virtual box, homestead,... he just tell the student to install it blindly. I have no idea what is Laravel, what is homestead, what is git, why do I use them.

From the beginning of the lecture, this instructor doesn't tell the student exact reason why do I need to install Laravel, Virtual box, homestead,... he just tell the student to install it blindly. results.content: Much worse than the average Udemy course, which is already a very low bar. I stopped a few minutes into Section 3, the very first lesson where you begin coding. You are immediately thrown into employing several concepts which you haven't yet learned about, with almost no explanation as to what's being done and why. How can I use Service Containers, and write Controllers and Twig templates when I haven't learned how to do any of that, or how any of it works, or why? In the official Symfony documentation, the article about Service Containers is found well past the mid-point of the Getting Started guide: after setting up a basic page, after learning about Symfony's routing system, after learning about controllers in Symfony. To make it even worse, the instructor uses tons of shortcuts provided by his IDE, producing several lines of code at once without any explanations, and quickly changes windows so you have to pause, rewind, pause, to check your code against his. I jumped ahead to a few other lectures and it doesn't seem to get better. I bought this course months ago and wish I could get my money back because it seems I'll be learning from the Symfony docs and other instructors instead. Maybe I'll return after getting the basics of Symfony down, but probably not.
